awd_titl_txt: Metal-Oxo and Metal-Peroxo Intermediates in Oxidative Catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor John Groves of Princeton University is developing catalysts that can form carbon-fluorine bonds in hydrocarbons.  Researchers on this project are also studying the reaction mechanisms and the factors that control the chemistry of the catalytic reactions, which will help to optimize the outcomes of the catalysis and to add to our fundamental knowledge base about chemistry.  Hydrocarbon transformations play central roles in the chemical process industry and the global energy budget. Compounds that contain carbon-fluorine bonds are important for a range of technologies, including those involving PET (Positron Emission Tomography) scans, and the production of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and coatings.  So the chemistry for advanced technological opportunities in the 21st century and to train the teachers of science for the future. 

Professor Groves is developing new methods for the catalytic oxygenation, fluorination and pseudo-halogenation of aliphatic carbon-hydrogen bonds. Such processes continue to be of fundamental interest and of greatly increasing economic value. The development of such novel oxidative processes requires a thorough understanding of the mechanisms of metal-mediated oxygen, and halogen, activation and transfer.  One ongoing aspect of the project involves characterizing reactive metal oxo and metal peroxo intermediates and elucidating the nature of their reactions with organic substrates.  This research is addressing five inter-related areas: (1) New methods and mechanisms of fluorination of unactivated C-H bonds, (2) New catalytic methods for pseudo-halide transfer to C-H bonds for carbon-nitrogen bond formation, (3) Using protons to tune catalytic C-H bond oxygenation in the regime of entropy control, (4) Energy landscapes for electrocatalytic oxygen transfer to and from oxygen and halogens, (5) C-H oxygenations by high-valent iodyl and iodosyl cations for natural gas partial oxidation.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report - Metal-Oxo and Metal-Peroxo Intermediates in Oxidative Catalysis

More than 95% of chemical industry products are derived from a small slate of simple building blocks, predominantly through oxygenation, C-C bond formation, halogenation or amination. C-H bonds are ubiquitous in commodity chemicals, building blocks and end products, but current technologies for C-H transformations still lack sufficient generality and selectivity. Metalloenzymes mediate a vast array of oxidative C-H to C-X interconversions with exquisite selectivity, although their broad application has been hampered by generally short life spans.

The goals of this program have been to understand and harness the breadth of strategies for hydrocarbon C-H activation chemistry currently being practiced by microorganisms, which use transition metal chemistry of abundant, first-row elements such as iron and manganese. Insights derived from synthetic, biomimetic systems have led to new catalysts, new chemical transformations, and have helped to define a conceptual basis to understand these processes. This endeavor has provided new methods of late-stage drug and agrochemical diversification, metabolite identification, new opportunities for energy transduction with hydrocarbons, new concepts for the development of fuel cells and new processes for disinfecting bioterrorism agents. Broad application of this chemistry could have tremendous impact on the nation's and the world's chemical and energy economies. Improvements in catalytic processes could result in up to 13 EJ/year in reduced energy use. Our approach involves direct kinetic and spectroscopic characterization of reactive metal-X intermediates under conditions of active, fast catalysis.

Broader Impacts. This project has helped train the personnel that are necessary for the nation to achieve the technological advances offered by these discoveries and the teachers of science for the future. Human health is impacted by the selectivity of chemical and biochemical catalysis that is necessary for the pharmaceutical industry to produce new and pure drugs and precursor molecules cleanly and efficiently. For example, catalytic processes can replace reagents that are toxic or explosive with more benign and less expensive catalysts such as iron and manganese. New catalytic technologies are also needed to allow the world economy to capture the vast resources of natural gas, which are now largely wasted, and to give high value added to petroleum feed stocks such as light hydrocarbons and olefins. New discoveries in oxidative catalysis are necessary to address these scientific, technological and environmental challenges such as reducing the huge energy burden of syngas production at very high temperatures.  

Graduate students, postdoctoral research associates and undergraduates being trained in the group, ten men and nine women during 2014-2019, gave 25 presentations at a variety of national and international meetings. Dr. Groves was a mentoring faculty at the Graduate Research Seminar in Bioinorganic Chemistry in 2015. Six group members have accepted faculty positions over the last grant period. There have been significant opportunities for undergraduates and high school students to have research experiences in our lab at Princeton. In 2014 we participated in the Girls' Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics Summer Program (GSTEM) organized by the NYU Courant Institute. Our lab has also participated in the Princeton Chemistry summer research diversity program aimed at URM undergraduates since its inception in 2014. Dr. Groves was a contributing reviewer of the 2016 NAS report on Effective Chemistry Communication.

Intellectual merit. With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Groves of Princeton University has developed new methods for the catalytic oxygenation, fluorination and pseudo-halogenation of C-H bonds. During the last grant period there was significant progress in five inter-related areas:

(1) New methods and mechanisms of [19F] and [18F] fluorination of unactivated C-H bonds,

(2) New catalytic methods for pseudo-halide (azide and isocyanate) transfer to C-H bonds,

(3) Using protons to tune catalytic C-H bond oxygenation in the regime of entropy control,

(4) Energy landscapes for electrocatalytic oxygen transfer to and from oxygen and halogens,

(5) C-H oxygenations by high-valent iodyl and iodosyl cations.

Dr. Groves presented 40 invited lectures and seminars nationally and internationally and 30 research publications during 2014-2019.

 


Last Modified: 05/16/2019
Modified by: John T Groves
